awd_titl_txt: Human-Inspired Balance Control of Bipedal Walkers with Foot Slip
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will contribute to the national welfare, health and prosperity by advancing mathematical dynamic models that can accurately capture and predict slip-and-fall accidents. Unintentional falls are the leading cause of nonfatal human injuries and the second leading cause of accidental deaths. The fall-related economic and societal costs for elders and professional workers are very substantial, and foot slippage is one of the major causes.  This project will develop mathematical models and balance control strategies informed by human motor skills. In collaboration with Kessler Institute for Rehabilitation, this knowledge will enable development of innovative personalized assistive and rehabilitation technology for prevention of slip-induced falls. The researchers will also develop a number of integrated research and education programs to attract students from underrepresented groups into engineering and involve undergraduate students into research.

Slip-and-fall consists of a series of continuously rapidly changing, whole-body human movements. It is challenging to capture and model human motion and reaction to slip due to complex slip biomechanics, human interactive neuro-musculoskeletal control and lack of real-time sensing and assistive technologies for reliably detecting the foot slip and helping design bipedal balance control under slip. The project will emphasize (1) the development of new dynamics models to understand and capture the bipedal walking locomotion under slip; (2) a new human-inspired balance recovery design to prevent slip-induced falls; and (3) experimental validation and testbed development to real-time detect slip and effectively prevent slip-induced falls. The new knowledge and design tools developed in this project will also serve as a cornerstone to further advance understanding, modeling and control of unsteady, unstable, agile bipedal locomotion and performance.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Unintentional falls is the leading cause of nonfatal human injuries and the second leading cause of the accidental deaths. The fall-related economic and societal costs for elders and professional workers are enormous. In the US only, the fall-related costs for the elderly were over 19 billion US dollars in 2000 and the costs are likely to increase in the future due to the aging population. The fall-related injuries for professional workers also increase by 42% from 2008 to 2012 in the US. Foot slip is one of the major causes for falling injuries. However, current research and knowledge lack theories and design tools for effectively modeling and balance control strategies for bipedal walkers under slip and thus preventing fall injuries and losses. The main goal of this project is to develop new dynamic models and human-inspired balance control for bipedal walkers with foot slip.

Over the past four years, the PI has accomplished various research tasks to develop new modeling and control strategies for bipedal walkers with foot slip in an integrated research-education plan. The main outcomes of the project lie in several aspects: (1) a new two-mass linear inverted pendulum model was developed to capture the bipedal walker motion under foot slip; (2) a new recoverability analytical method to compute safe, recoverable and fall regions for bipedal motion; (3) new integrated step planning and balance recovery control design for bipedal walkers with foot slip; (4) development of assist-as-needed control strategy for bilateral lightweight, highly-backdrivable soft knee exoskeletons for human walking with foot slip; (5) extensive bipedal robot and human subject experiments were conducted for testing and validation. More than 10 journal and conference publications have been produced and supported by the project. A number of research activities were integrated into the education programs to attract students from underrepresented groups into engineering fields, such as participating the Rutgers SUPER and LSAMP programs and hosting more than 4 freshmen female students, supporting more than 4 senior design projects, and attracting more than 6 undergraduate students to conduct research assistance.
